## Overview

This manuscript, “Active Inference as a Meta-Pragmatic and Meta-Epistemic Method,” presents a novel framework for understanding cognitive science and cognitive security implications. It proposes a (2 ×2) matrix structure that organizes Active Inference’s operation across four distinct quadrants – data processing, meta-data organization, reflective processing, and higher-order reasoning – highlighting its capacity for meta-level specification and control. The core argument centers on Active Inference’s ability to transcend traditional cognitive models by allowing researchers to explicitly design the frameworks within which cognition occurs, fundamentally shifting the research focus.

This framework is built upon the core principles of the Free Energy Principle, utilizing generative models (A, B, C, and D matrices) to define epistemic and pragmatic landscapes. The key methodological contribution is the systematic analysis of how these matrices interact to drive cognitive processes, allowing researchers to target specific processing levels and explore the consequences of different framework specifications. The manuscript demonstrates this approach through detailed mathematical formulations and conceptual examples, illustrating the framework’s applicability across diverse cognitive domains.
